comments.commentBody: The US should not stand in the way of a positive UN vote recognizing Palestine's legitimate request for recognition.  The US should not further isolate itself from the rest of the world as a rubber stamp for the conservative party within Israel.  Obama needs to show some backbone for once.

I can not believe the tone of this administration and these NYT commenters.  For people to turn against Israel after the  territorial   wars waged against  Israel  and the totally egregious comments by the Arab leaders, it would seem  that the Obama crowd has lost their moral compass and common sense. But given their other policies, that would just seem to be "business"  as usual...for their  teleprompter/ looking good   mind set...

This comments here, as usual, are very heavily weighted against Israel.
Whenever I see this, I always have to wonder why people care so much that there are only 50 Muslim majority countries in the world instead
of 51. Or is it that what these people really care about is that there is one (very small) Jewish country in the world instead of none?

Two points about Obama's speech:

1. He must realize, the 1949 armistice lines (dubbed 1967 boundaries) are simply a none starter for Arab Israeli peace. Even UN Security Council Resolution, 242, which was desived to achieve Arab Israeli peace, accepted by all parties, including the PLO, has been the basis for all peace talks and actual agreements does not even suggest such future borders.

2. Obama should have addressed directly and forcefully the Arabs' categorical refusal to accept Israel's RIGHT to be, to exist as the nation-state of the Jewish people on ANY parcel of land between the River and the Sea. This refusal has been the very core of the conflict, yet Mr. Obama has refused to address it.

No. 2 -- "You want to keep it, so be it."

That land is very painfully obviously not empty. You take it, you take the people on it. We might help you with that.

You try to take it without the people, you will lose more than our $3 billion/yr in military grants.

yes, we have reached a turning point. With the Arab spring moving on, the relevance of Israel becomes less and less important. If the old dogma holds that "America has no friends but only interests", then the Israelis better start behaving.

I remember all of the liberal trashing of Bush for being  such an arrogant American. How strange that this current administration feels so comfortable "lecturing" the rest of the world, throwing our allies under the bus, and wallowing in teleprompter proclamations to the globe!  Talk about arrogance. Clueless. Naive.  Can only imagine how disgusting this newly minted American "superiority" must seem to the rest of the world. Especially after this  White House crowd has spent so much time apologizing for what they termed past  errors of   American arrogance. Guess it was just classic projection!   Hurry up election of 2012.  We definitely need a "change."

If he committed the crime, let him do the time. Until then I'll reserve my judgement. I do find it sad though that Americans need such a story to feel good about themselves. I mean, for a second, look at yourselves rubbing it in and making all sorts of claims about how great America is by comparison. Did you forget what goes on every day in this country? Don't you watch the news?

DSK  and Assange offer humanity a valuable lesson. When you go to another country without diplomatic immunity, you become subject to the legal system  (de jure and de facto) of that country . To avoid that,don't go there.

"He said that the two leaders had to figure out a way to work together to stop a United Nations vote that could harm both the United States and Israel."

That is easy: both countries should vote for a U.N. resolution in favor of a Palestinian nation based on the 1967 borders.

Now Mr. Obama needs to step back.  Withhold the veto and let Europe do its job.  Palestinian statehood comes one step at a time.  Let the General assembly declare a Palestinian state.  That will put real pressure on Mr. NetanYAHOO and let the Israeli peacemakers have some breathing room.  Mr. NetanYAHOO's passive-aggressiveness will create an explosive condition.  He is of course hoping that in the midst of chaos, he can take a bit more land and perhaps push out a few more Palestinians--all justified by some potential foolish desperate act by a Palestinian.

The Isrealis want our country to be their lacky and put pressure on our European allies to vote against the United Nations recognition of Palestine as a full member?  Let the Israelis do their own heavy lifting.  After stiffing our country and not extending the settlement freeze, which exposed how limited our power is, the call by Israel for us to now exercise our power to help them, is for those who don't know what the word means, a wonderful example of chutzpah.
Let's support Christine Lagarde for managing director.  The IMF's 'sexual norms' would surely change.

What happens when an organization is dominated by men? What type of culture emerges?

This article confirms what we all know: and it is that men, no matter how outwardly exemplary and well educated they may be, still have the ability to behave in a predatory manner, particularly when protected by a fraternity of colleagues. The Catholic Church would have to be the ultimate example of masculine power and how destructive it can be.

What is most lethal and disturbing, is the willingness of male colleagues to engage in cover-ups allowing unethical and criminal behavior to continue, often for decades, before it is exposed and halted.

The IMF is also top heavy with men in senior positions. This must be rectified and a sincere effort be made to promote qualified women to leadership.

Consider the condition of human society at present. If we are to have a future, it is imperative that women be promoted to leadership in EVERY sphere. This is our best hope to create a just, fair and decent world.

Michael Lewis gives you the "winner" vibe in "LIAR'S POKER." The IMF is testosterone city, and no doubt most subscribe to Kissinger's dictum: "Power is the ultimate aphrodisiac."

"Why get a ticket to Chicago if you're not going to Chicago?" Since the dawn of man, it is a truism: "women are prey" -- and so are "pretty boys." There can be little doubt that "women on the prowl" in Washington, D.C. know just what they're looking for.

As long as power-broker women are looking for alpha dog mates, it's going to be mighty hard for women not to be prey at the IMF and all such "corridors" of testosterone-heavy power.

If a woman can't hold her own at the IMF, she doesn't belong there. The world of men vying for top spot is BRUTAL, driven by PRIMITIVE DNA. Just read ADAM'S CURSE. Actually, it's a miracle that in the ordinary run of life in the U.S.A. so many men have respect for women and exercise restraint over their primitive impulses.

If you COURT excitement and power, be prepared for the risks. Let's not be so naive, my sisters. Learn from women who have made it on their terms (whatever they may be), and play your cards as best you can. This is REALITY.

On the other hand, the women can try WALKING AWAY from money. Millions have done it. Choose integrity OR power/glory/gold. No crybabies need apply. If you don't like what you get, WALK and FILE SUIT.

I don't buy the party line.

Give me a break. Were that work at the IMF or World Bank were so sexually charged. You're writing about people who were really good at calculus in high school. When the suits are tailored, it's to minimize the bulge around the middle from long hours putting statistical tables or policy memos together.
I have participated in many "trips abroad" with the IMF and the World Bank. The behavior is workaholic and focused on issues like fiscal imbalances. While there are adults involved, and so affairs and bad and good things happen, the norm is long hours of meetings and email. It's a very nerdy and ambitious crowd of people anxious to get ahead.

I agree with @CK- There is a major difference between the plenty of women who are 'working it' at on so many levels and the ones who are being intimidated by a superior, an employer. You can not put them all in the same category. This is a broader discussion and must have keep in mind that there are different realities. Some of them may not please all women, nevertheless, it is true. I wouldn´t say that it is only a matter of women being in high heels, tight skirts and generally come-hither outfits but in their attitude and decisions. If some decide to have affairs and sexual encounters with employers or subordinates, well, that´s their choice. I should not taint the rest who do not, have different moral values and just might have to fight harder to achieve the same or even better results. This is not a simple topic and can not be turned it into a provincial moralistic one.

High heels, tight skirts and come-hither outfits are not always intended to be invitations for an intimate liaison but, as we see in comment #1, can be instead misinterpreted as such.

It's always good to make certain what the intention is before jumping to conclusions. Furthermore, to misjudge how a woman dresses is nearly as damaging as blaming the victim of a rape rather than blaming the rapist.
Isn't it about time that IMF and World Bank employees pay their fair share of federal taxes?  They are currently - but not for long - exempt from federal taxes.  They had a break way too long.

Slightly unreal.

Obama merely rather meekly recapitulated what has been US policy since 1967. He even went so far as to emphasize that there should be 'territorial swaps,' and that the Palestinian 'state' should be unarmed, and he didn't even remind Israel that her settlements are illegal, against US policy, and a violation of her own commitments.

It was a display of submissive piddling. But apparently that's not even enough. Netanyahu is throwing a fit.

We need a reality check. This ranting monster we kowtow to, appease with billions, and immolate our entire international position on behalf of is roughly the size of Togo and about the same distance away. We should pay it about the same amount of attention.
Go a head obama vote at the UN to do that. Just because the Un says it is so it will happen. obama is dreaming again some one wake him up. Wake him up before he starts WWIII

that so many reactors Mark 1 and other models, on land under sea and in outer space have been functioning, with so few accidents, for so long is a testament to man's ingenuity....the relative few accidents incurred since the inception of nuclear generated electricity, alongside the one two earthquake/tsunami punch resulting in the current Fukushida basket case scenario speak well for precaution minded nuclear industrialist throughout.
Bluntly, the problem with the American Nuclear industry is the lack of progress with Yucca Mountain, the how to dispose of nuclear waste safely when perfect safety is demanded.
The lack of serious accidents in the US makes us an inexperienced support group when many could use a helpful quick fix for the problems by the Japanese seashore. Japanese authorities should be encouraged to reach out and establish a dialogue if not ask for help from Chernobyl Scientists, Engineers and Tecchies with past hands on experience at tackling a difficult hot topic.

It is time for the gloves to come off, Mr. President!

Last time you were firm but civil in dealing with Netenyahu. I sincerely hope you will follow through on the speech you made today. I applaud you for saying what many prior U.S. Presidents have been afraid to say, fearing retaliation from AIPAC. I applaud you for putting your re-election at jeopardy to "say the right thing"!

For obvious reasons, it is in the interest of the United States to see peace in the Middle East. Israel needs to understand this. Israel also needs to realize that it is in their long term interest to make peace with their brethren, the Arab Palestinians. After all they are from the same stock: Phillistines. What separates them is religion, which has created more hate in this World than love. If they were to step back they would realize that they are all human beings and all "God's Chosen People". God does not discriminate.

Of course, in order to do this, both sides need to forget the bloodshed and mistakes of the past and accept each other as they are. It means that all the leaders have to embrace a bold (and novel) approach, even if it means losing the next election. It means that Arab Palestinians accept that Israel is a reality that is not going to go away. Israel needs to treat its brethren fairly and justly. Arab Palestinians need to stop lobbying rockets across the border and Israel needs to stop taking all the prime land and water resources away from Arab Palestinians.

As Lord Acton said: "A politician is person who looks to the next election. A Statesman is a person who looks to the next generation". I hope both you and Prime Minister Netenyahu can rise above the rabble and act like Statesmen and not mere politicians.

Most Americans are tired of supporting, politically, financially and militarily, our alleged ally in the Middle East. Israel is not our 51st State.

Imagine a Democratic-led Congress accepting a request for a Joint Session address by the leader of a country whose policies are at odds with those of a sitting Republican president.

Can you imagine the outrage from the right-wing media? They'd be so furious and indignant, steam would practically shoot out their ears. The cries of treason would be never-ending.

But if the president is a Democrat and the Congress is led by Republicans, then no matter.

The hypocrisy of the Republican party is so par for the course these days, it's not even surprising anymore.

Of course, with Israel, there's obviously a "special" relationship to consider. A one-sided relationship that, for some reason (which of course, we're not allowed to say out loud in polite company) shows no sign of changing despite the enormous costs to the USA.

What if Obama were to not veto the UN vote in September? What if - given Americans' current distaste for foreign aid - we were to cut off the $3B Israel leeches off this country?

There are literally higher chances of pigs flying than either of those two things happening.

And why?

Because, despite the enormous cost to the USA of writing a yearly check to Israel worth billions of dollars, and the enormous cost of standing with them when it clearly goes against our national interest, our politicians will not do a thing to change the dynamic. To, you know, pursue the national interest.

Why would that be?
Enough!  Let the cards fall where they may.
